commit_message:
Continue renaming volume_utils (core)

Now that volume_utils has been renamed, import it
and use it consistently everywhere.

Change-Id: I6a74f664ff890ff3f24f715a1e93df7e0384aa6b

subject: connectors/nvme: Wait until nvme device shows up in kernel
messages:
[{'account_id': 30729, 'date': '2019-09-12 15:53:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-09-12 15:56:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Is there a bug files for this? If so, it would be good to link to that in the commit message.

The reason I ask is we would be able to backport bugfixes easily and this looks like something we may want to. Linking to a bug isn't strictly required to do so, but it makes it easy to track where we want to make sure it gets fixed."}, {'account_id': 30729, 'date': '2019-09-12 16:14:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 30729, 'date': '2019-09-12 16:15:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Sean McGinnis. I put this changes into original patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672031/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-12 15:53:12.000000000', 'message': 'connectors/nvme: Wait until nvme device shows up in kernel

When using nvme connect NNMe device
does not show up immediately in kernel.

Change-Id: I452ddd668ed043a68099c96dd2af035c09d6f5d1
Signed-off-by: Pawel Kaminski <pawelx.kaminski@intel.com>
'}]
commit_message:
connectors/nvme: Wait until nvme device shows up in kernel

When using nvme connect NNMe device
does not show up immediately in kernel.

Change-Id: I452ddd668ed043a68099c96dd2af035c09d6f5d1
Signed-off-by: Pawel Kaminski <pawelx.kaminski@intel.com>

(4 comments)

Thanks for the refactoring Eric.
I see most of the imports done as
`from cinder.volume import volume_utils as {volutils|vol_utils|v_utils|utils}`
From a consistency point of view, we should be using only one name which we have designated here 'volume_utils'(as most of the files are in favor of it).
Maybe i'm wrong, maybe this will require a lot more work but importing the module as 
`from cinder.volume import volume_utils as utils`
doesn't seem right for the purpose of the patch."}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2019-09-05 13:51:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Anywhere that's still doing
    `from cinder.volume import volume_utils as {volutils|vol_utils|v_utils|utils}`


is something that will be fixed up in a later patch.  The problem is, this patch already conflicts with... everything, and trying to fix all of them in one shot is going to be impossible to merge unless folks actually plan a specific time to merge this patch.  So I'd rather just get the guts of it landed and then polish things up w/o having to rebase this over and over."}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2019-09-05 13:54:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I also skipped updating some places because it pushed line lengths to over 80 chars, which means rearranging the code, which means it's harder to review... and more work if this doesn't get merged soon.  Maybe I'll post a second patch to cover more of these changes."}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2019-09-05 14:00:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 21863, 'date': '2019-09-05 15:19:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Rename volume/utils.py to volume/volume_utils.py

Much of our code renames this at import already --
just name it "volume_utils" for consistency, and
to make code that imports other modules named "utils"
less confusing.

Change-Id: I3cdf445ac9ab89b3b4c221ed2723835e09d48a53

commit_message:
Check if volume paths exist before executing Docker.

If the file to be mounted doesn't exist, Docker version 1.13.1
creates a directory in it's place. This behavior is different from
Podman's, which throws an error. We want to replicate the Podman
behavior. Creating directories in place of files causes errors
which are very difficult to diagnose.

Related-Bug #1830734

Change-Id: Ibc458d3badb807a0deef5a799db6682d7128dbc1
(cherry picked from commit 6ca0170eebfad694d6d9e5e0d25f9f1b2fa971ce)

commit_message:
Check if volume paths exist before executing Docker.

If the file to be mounted doesn't exist, Docker version 1.13.1
creates a directory in it's place. This behavior is different from
Podman's, which throws an error. We want to replicate the Podman
behavior. Creating directories in place of files causes errors
which are very difficult to diagnose.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675162
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675262
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/673798
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/673797
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675666
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675265

Related-Bug #1830734

Change-Id: Ibc458d3badb807a0deef5a799db6682d7128dbc1

commit_message:
Check if volume paths exist before executing Docker.

If the file to be mounted doesn't exist, Docker version 1.13.1
creates a directory in it's place. This behavior is different from
Podman's, which throws an error. We want to replicate the Podman
behavior. Creating directories in place of files causes errors
which are very difficult to diagnose.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675356
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675357
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675358
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675359
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675360
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675668
Related-Bug #1830734

Change-Id: Ibc458d3badb807a0deef5a799db6682d7128dbc1
(cherry picked from commit 6ca0170eebfad694d6d9e5e0d25f9f1b2fa971ce)

commit_message:
Update json module to jsonutils

oslo project provide jsonutils, and murano use it in many place[1],
this PS to update the remained json module to oslo jsonutils for
consistency.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/murano/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=jsonutils&type=

Change-Id: I68ec0684484af61928f3adc4f9d93f6480a279dd

commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

1. Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.
2. cleanup of .keys() from dict_object.keys() *in* operator

Change-Id: I74df3101fecdcf2f5d5e107c87e9445217d73b09

commit_message:
Convert timestamps to strs before passing them to gnocchiclient

It seems like the way gnocchiclient serializes timezone-aware datetime
objects causes punctual random failures from gnocchi's API. Converting
datetime objects to strings before passing them to gnocchiclient
solves this issue.

Change-Id: Ifb874597c59f3f4dbd5fcb67edac3e456dd106e7

commit_message:
Fix catching driver exceptions

octavia_lib driver exceptions were not cought by call_provider
This patch add those exceptions, and also handles the native NotImplementedError
which does nto have all the expected fields.

Change-Id: I1a566353b7fb125184849b3a0f864d3ef6896d94

commit_message:
Add response schema validation for volume quota_set

This is to add response schema validation for volume
quota_set, also to remove the fields check in testcases.

Change-Id: Id80025119100bb4072fbefa9cc4438eab71dbe6d

subject: Revert "Disable fortnebula cloud"
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6469, 'name': 'Carlos Gon√ßalves', 'display_name': 'Carlos Goncalves', 'email': 'cgoncalves@redhat.com', 'username': 'cgoncalves'}, {'_account_id': 6547, 'name': 'Andreas Jaeger', 'email': 'jaegerandi@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaegerandi'}, {'_account_id': 11604, 'name': 'sean mooney', 'email': 'smooney@redhat.com', 'username': 'sean-k-mooney'}, {'_account_id': 11628, 'name': 'Michael Johnson', 'email': 'johnsomor@gmail.com', 'username': 'johnsom'}, {'_account_id': 13252, 'name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott', 'display_name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott (frickler)', 'email': 'frickler@offenerstapel.de', 'username': 'jrosenboom'}, {'_account_id': 20754, 'name': 'Donny Davis', 'email': 'donny@fortnebula.com', 'username': 'donnydavis'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-09-12 12:29:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-09-12 13:58:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Given we know there are IPv6 issues here, maybe we should wait until next week (post feature freeze) for this.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-09-12 13:58:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Fortnebula has been quite unstable for weeks and even more lately. Are we sure all connectivity issues have been solved? This week is feature freeze. Many projects are merging feature patches. Maybe not a good time to try-and-check Fortnebula...'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-09-12 14:12:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 20754, 'date': '2019-09-12 14:52:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

The FN network issues were due to IPv6 retransmits. That should be solved with the reduction in MTU for the tenant network. All of the test nodes were being NAT to the mirror via IPv4 which resulted in the unreliable connections. 

Resolution is to lower the MTU for the tenant network - DONE
Additionally move the NAT router into Openstack so connections don't go all the way up and back down the FN Infrastructe - DONE"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-09-12 15:00:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

we would like to use FN to do some testing that can only be done there so if it can be renabled before FF that woudl be better then after form a nova point of view. i am going to use vexhost to test as much as i can with out FN but we wont be able to test both  multi numa pinning without FN in ci.

we can do single numa pinning and migration so that will hopefully be good enough and il  manually test multi nuam if i have  time'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-09-12 15:09:41.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Let'S do it stepwise..."}]

subject: Update the VM Image Guide
messages:
[{'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-08-27 14:15:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-08-27 16:08:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

When I looked at the rendered HTML, I noticed the following:

- The update page [1] has now a few contents. How about merging [1] into the parent page [2] ?
- Even after this patch, [2] seems to explain very similar information to the glance page linked from [1]. What do you think about this?

[1] https://12942841482e92c0cd55-0acfe5e696fda6aec28b6c718c3c4841.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/678856/1/check/build-tox-manuals-publishdocs/5e2173a/docs/image-guide/image-formats.html
[2] https://12942841482e92c0cd55-0acfe5e696fda6aec28b6c718c3c4841.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/678856/1/check/build-tox-manuals-publishdocs/5e2173a/docs/image-guide/introduction.html'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-08-27 20:18:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Akihiro: thanks for the review.  I agree that there's still a lot of redundancy and I should revise this patch.  How does this sound:

(1) Rewrite the Introduction page [2] to include some info about the concept of "container format", with a link to the Glance page that explains what the list of container_format identifiers are and what they mean; remove [1] completely.

(2) Add a paragraph on [2] explaining the concept of a disk format; merge the content in the description list of formats currently on [2] into the the Glance page that lists the disk_format identifiers.

(3) Merge the content from [3] into the Introduction page [2] and remove [3].

Let me know what you think.

[1] https://12942841482e92c0cd55-0acfe5e696fda6aec28b6c718c3c4841.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/678856/1/check/build-tox-manuals-publishdocs/5e2173a/docs/image-guide/image-formats.html
[2] https://12942841482e92c0cd55-0acfe5e696fda6aec28b6c718c3c4841.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/678856/1/check/build-tox-manuals-publishdocs/5e2173a/docs/image-guide/introduction.html
[3] https://12942841482e92c0cd55-0acfe5e696fda6aec28b6c718c3c4841.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/678856/1/check/build-tox-manuals-publishdocs/5e2173a/docs/image-guide/image-metadata.html'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-09-02 21:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-09-03 00:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-09-04 12:25:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Patch moving content into the Glance docs has merged: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/679692/1'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-09-04 14:23:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

thanks!'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-09-12 14:21:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(2 comments)'}]

commit_message:
Update the VM Image Guide

Moves the content of two sub-pages into the Introduction page.
The content that specified the legal values for the image properties
content_format and disk_format has been consolidated into the
documents that already describe that information that are maintained
by the Glance team.

Partial-bug: #1842343
Change-Id: I8885d76b55ed67e9c22b49c86c7e2a9bdfcf03c6

'}, {'created': '2019-09-12 14:01:10.000000000', 'message': "Fix functional tests

This patch is fixing the functional tests by forcing the use of the OVS
2.11 branch instead of master (that's adequate for queens).

The master branch has moved OVN out of it's repository as part of the
commit https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/1159033/ and the functional
script in ovsdbapp no long works.

Change-Id: I187b7a7951f1a13f4716a2451591416d2d6100f9
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Fix functional tests

This patch is fixing the functional tests by forcing the use of the OVS
2.11 branch instead of master (that's adequate for queens).

The master branch has moved OVN out of it's repository as part of the
commit https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/1159033/ and the functional
script in ovsdbapp no long works.

Change-Id: I187b7a7951f1a13f4716a2451591416d2d6100f9
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

subject: Modified verbiage about how tokens are generated using Fernet keys
messages:
[{'account_id': 30944, 'date': '2019-09-09 05:20:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-09-09 05:20:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30944, 'date': '2019-09-10 17:49:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-09-12 14:37:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 30561, 'date': '2019-09-12 14:40:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Commented'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-21 13:01:10.000000000', 'message': 'Enable Swift Recon

This commit adds the necessary configuration to the Swift account,
container and object configuration files to enable the Swift recon
cli.

In order to give the object server on each Swift host access to the
recon files, a Docker volume is mounted into each container which
generates them. The volume is then mounted read only into the object
server container. Note that multiple containers append to the same
file. This should not be a problem since Swift uses a lock when
appending.

Change-Id: I343d8f45a78ebc3c11ed0c68fe8bec24f9ea7929
Co-authored-by: Doug Szumski <doug@stackhpc.com>

commit_message:
Enable Swift Recon

This commit adds the necessary configuration to the Swift account,
container and object configuration files to enable the Swift recon
cli.

In order to give the object server on each Swift host access to the
recon files, a Docker volume is mounted into each container which
generates them. The volume is then mounted read only into the object
server container. Note that multiple containers append to the same
file. This should not be a problem since Swift uses a lock when
appending.

Change-Id: I343d8f45a78ebc3c11ed0c68fe8bec24f9ea7929
Co-authored-by: Doug Szumski <doug@stackhpc.com>

commit_message:
Prepare for OSC 4.0 release

The major version of this package will sync with the major version
of OSC that it installs. The minor and patch versions will not be kept
in sync.

Change-Id: I4870bceb14045434b70fb79d7f8f2c72e19a6e9e
Signed-off-by: Dean Troyer <dtroyer@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add a "force_granularity" option to gnocchi collector's extra_args

This adds an option allowing to force the granularity to use when doing metric
aggregations. If not specified or set to 0, the lowest available aggregation
method will be used.

Change-Id: I1ad36c3ac4125b4af285fddc3a4a649d5dc3b395

commit_message:
Fixing broken links

This also removes reference to the deprecated DevStack gate.
A few links have been removed, namely anything relating to
/elements/ as it doesn't appear to exist anymore and I cannot
find any reference to it. If anyone can point me in the right
direction, that would be appreciated.

commit_message:
Set osd_scenario variable during P->Q upgrade.

Recent changes in ceph-ansible require osd_scenario variable to
be set. Otherwise upgrade fails like:
  [ERROR]: [ceph-0] Reason: -> item[0] key did not match 'osd_scenario'
  (required item in schema is missing: osd_scenario)

Change-Id: I1bc4b8421eafd6db16327bbe26852daa05415e9e

fair enough, lgtm'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-07-31 18:27:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

It seems we have another implementation of nearly the same thing already in review at:

 https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658161

Should one of these two be abandoned?'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-07-31 18:35:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Thanks for the submission Matt. I'm putting a -1 since this could be improved with a CI test.

This patch should include a change to the ci scenario 001, just add an arbitrary key/value which doesn't break ceph in the new sections so we can see it in the deploy artifacts. That will prove it works. 

The submission at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658161 is in the process of adding that that. If that one wasn't already close I'd be for merging this (after it had the CI change) but we probably don't need two of the same submission."}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-08-01 06:26:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Hi,
thank you for this review.
I started thinking about giving the ability to override different sections than "global" in ceph.conf and I created the [1] for this purpose.
After a couple of reviews I figured out we need a more generic way to handle the CephConfigOverrides parameter, avoiding to expose additional params from the templates, but just manipulating the json input coming from CephConfigOverrides parameter.
Here [2] my attempt to do that, give me some feedback and let's come to a concrete conclusion.

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/ceph-config-overrides
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658161'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-09-12 13:51:37.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Since we now have this feature from this review I'm abandoning this old review. If you need it restored for some reason just ask.
 https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658161"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-27 07:30:59.000000000', 'message': 'Allow overriding client and osd stanzas

Change-Id: I08961b87d47a9bb9dd3035d9a657a4fa4240a797
'}, {'created': '2019-07-27 07:33:55.000000000', 'message': '[CEPH] Allow overriding client and osd stanzas

Override the client and osd stanzas to apply custom
tunables for OSD and Cliet configurations for the
ceph.conf file.

Change-Id: I08961b87d47a9bb9dd3035d9a657a4fa4240a797
'}, {'created': '2019-07-27 14:39:27.000000000', 'message': '[CEPH] Allow overriding client and osd stanzas

Add two new params CephOSDConfigOverride and
CephClientConfigOverride to add custom OSD and
Client configuration tunables for ceph.conf.

In the field we use these values to tune OSD
and Ceph client behavior.

Change-Id: I08961b87d47a9bb9dd3035d9a657a4fa4240a797
'}]
commit_message:
[CEPH] Allow overriding client and osd stanzas

Add two new params CephOSDConfigOverride and
CephClientConfigOverride to add custom OSD and
Client configuration tunables for ceph.conf.

In the field we use these values to tune OSD
and Ceph client behavior.

Change-Id: I08961b87d47a9bb9dd3035d9a657a4fa4240a797

commit_message:
Revert "Blacklist bandit 1.6.0"

This reverts commit ebac8330d8ac81c491a1cb0e16eb23b93d7932ee.

Using the glob that I had not yet had enough coffee to do correctly is a
better solution, and allows us to fix new failures in 1.6.0 which would
break us again when 1.6.1 was released.

Change-Id: Ica473ba71b224cdc0acf815f82d534b6c70a7f54
(cherry picked from commit dc3175afb16fedaf5216b5d4a7a521d16636b4d1)

(1 comment)

I support the need for a helper to manage these, but I question the need for stashing them in charm state.

It appears we can query this state from Ceph itself, what is the reason to keep the extra state in the charm?

Will this be used outside the ``ceph-mon`` charm?'}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2019-09-12 13:00:37.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

commit_message:
Manager module should be able to be enabled

Ceph adds mgr modules during upgrades, so it should be possible
to initialize those modules on cluster upgrade or setup.

Change-Id: I3081911858c0a5e1f822dccbd36f0c6a97248598

commit_message:
Allow venv python interpreter to be overridden

Also allow a default var to be specified per distro, maintaining
the current functionality for tripleo without requiring an override.

Change-Id: I99e0082a748d62ed129a860c6f16c523dec8d50e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-21 18:33:05.000000000', 'message': '3PAR: Add config for NSP single path attach

This fix aims to resolve below mentioned bugs:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/os-brick/+bug/1812665
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1809249
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1734917

Given a system connected to HPE 3PAR via FC and multipath is disabled.
When user tries to create bootable volume, it fails intermittently
with following error:

    Fibre Channel volume device not found

This happens when a zone is created using second or later target nsp
from 3PAR backend. In this case, HPE 3PAR client code picks up first
target nsp to form initiator target map.

To avoid above mentioned failure, user can specify target nsp in 3PAR
backend section of cinder.conf as follows:

    hpe3par_target_nsp = <n:s:p>

This target information is read from cinder.conf and respective
wwn information is fetched. Later initiator target map is created
using wwn information and bootable volume is created successfully.

Change-Id: I2da5d4a0334f07967af5ff7aaa39a0ecc4b12204
Closes-bug: #1809249
Closes-bug: #1812665
Closes-bug: #1734917

commit_message:
3PAR: Add config for NSP single path attach

This fix aims to resolve below mentioned bugs:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/os-brick/+bug/1812665
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1809249
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1734917

Given a system connected to HPE 3PAR via FC and multipath is disabled.
When user tries to create bootable volume, it fails intermittently
with following error:

    Fibre Channel volume device not found

This happens when a zone is created using second or later target nsp
from 3PAR backend. In this case, HPE 3PAR client code picks up first
target nsp to form initiator target map.

To avoid above mentioned failure, user can specify target nsp in 3PAR
backend section of cinder.conf as follows:

    hpe3par_target_nsp = <n:s:p>

This target information is read from cinder.conf and respective
wwn information is fetched. Later initiator target map is created
using wwn information and bootable volume is created successfully.

Change-Id: I2da5d4a0334f07967af5ff7aaa39a0ecc4b12204
Closes-bug: #1809249
Closes-bug: #1812665
Closes-bug: #1734917
(cherry picked from commit 9e122f11661b766b2fe2c3a12bab35ef6e14f3f1)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-11 15:54:36.000000000', 'message': 'healthcheck_port: run ss -ntp with sudo

The output of "ss" is different if you run it as root, or as the user
which is used to execute the process we want to monitor.

e.g. nova-conuductor (check reported bug)

()[root@undercloud /]$ ss -ntp | grep -E ":($ports).*,pid=($pids),"
(empty output)

()[root@undercloud /]$ sudo -u nova ss -ntp | grep -E ":($ports).*,pid=($pids),"
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:56959  192.168.24.3:3306  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=25,fd=7))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:46860  192.168.24.3:3306  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=26,fd=7))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:55918  192.168.24.1:5672  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=26,fd=8))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:56786  192.168.24.1:5672  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=26,fd=9))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:55920  192.168.24.1:5672  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=25,fd=8))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:57238  192.168.24.3:3306  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=25,fd=10))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:56840  192.168.24.1:5672  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=25,fd=9))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:35115  192.168.24.3:3306  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=26,fd=10)

(output was implified for the commit message)

So the idea of this patch is to introduce a new function,
get_user_from_process() which will figure out what user runs the
process, by using pgrep and ps.

More infos about how the ps was done is documented in the code, but to
make it safer we grep the pid AND cmd to get accurate informations.

Then later in healthcheck_port, use the new function to figure out which
user is running the process, then run the "ss" with "sudo -u" to get the
accurate output and know if the process is actually connected to the
port that we want.

Change-Id: I7be514832fc7af8dbcfbafe15b2425db8dcfe3c7
Closes-Bug: #1843555
'}, {'created': '2019-09-11 16:00:21.000000000', 'message': 'healthcheck_port: run ss -ntp with sudo

commit_message:
healthcheck_port: run ss -ntp with sudo

The output of "ss" is different if you run it as root, or as the user
which is used to execute the process we want to monitor.

e.g. nova-conuductor (check reported bug)

()[root@undercloud /]$ ss -ntp | grep -E ":($ports).*,pid=($pids),"
(empty output)

()[root@undercloud /]$ sudo -u nova ss -ntp | grep -E ":($ports).*,pid=($pids),"
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:56959  192.168.24.3:3306  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=25,fd=7))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:46860  192.168.24.3:3306  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=26,fd=7))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:55918  192.168.24.1:5672  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=26,fd=8))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:56786  192.168.24.1:5672  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=26,fd=9))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:55920  192.168.24.1:5672  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=25,fd=8))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:57238  192.168.24.3:3306  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=25,fd=10))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:56840  192.168.24.1:5672  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=25,fd=9))
ESTAB  192.168.24.1:35115  192.168.24.3:3306  users:(("nova-conductor",pid=26,fd=10)

(output was implified for the commit message)

So the idea of this patch is to introduce a new function,
get_user_from_process() which will figure out what user runs the
process, by using pgrep and ps.

More infos about how the ps was done is documented in the code, but to
make it safer we grep the pid AND cmd to get accurate informations.

Then later in healthcheck_port, use the new function to figure out which
user is running the process, then run the "ss" with "sudo -u" to get the
accurate output and know if the process is actually connected to the
port that we want.

Change-Id: I7be514832fc7af8dbcfbafe15b2425db8dcfe3c7
Closes-Bug: #1843555

[WIP|DNM] testing uefi job with ubuntu bionic

Testing uefi job with new ovmf package and e1000 driver.

commit_message:
nova: Move manpages to doc package

manpages do not need to be installed on all nodes that have any nova
package installed. So only install manpages when the doc package is installed.

Change-Id: I65cc0137ab8950b4c01add7a1ca3fd7cd84240bd

[{'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-09-11 16:57:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-09-11 17:00:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

This can still succeed if we only got two of the notifications we really expected. Which isn't great test coverage.

The hard way would be to start introspecting the notifications and make sure we got the specific ones we care about, right?

But I'm good with this to get us moving; and we can do "hard way" later.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-09-11 17:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-09-11 17:03:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-09-11 17:16:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> The hard way would be to start introspecting the notifications and make sure we got the specific ones we care about, right?

Yeah, I wanted to avoid doing that but it's possible."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-09-11 17:18:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Actually I'm not totally sure what you're saying - but we should get the force complete end notification before the fake virt driver triggers the call to _post_live_migration because of this:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0575eabffb0f574942f8695bccc9dc48ad122d49/nova/virt/fake.py#L842

Ah, okay, so if we get to 6+, we know we've gotten *at least* the ones we care about.

Cool beans."}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2019-09-11 17:41:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-11 16:57:31.000000000', 'message': 'Fix race in _test_live_migration_force_complete

The number of versioned notifications received in the
_test_live_migration_force_complete method is racey since
by the time we check we could have entered _post_live_migration
and received up to four more notifications. This change softens
the assertion to go from "equal to 6" to "at least 6".

Change-Id: I98bbd6beaba1256f1c679af0c1eb8c7cad407e2b
Closes-Bug: #1843615
'}]
commit_message:
Fix race in _test_live_migration_force_complete

The number of versioned notifications received in the
_test_live_migration_force_complete method is racey since
by the time we check we could have entered _post_live_migration
and received up to four more notifications. This change softens
the assertion to go from "equal to 6" to "at least 6".

Change-Id: I98bbd6beaba1256f1c679af0c1eb8c7cad407e2b
Closes-Bug: #1843615

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-11 22:25:37.000000000', 'message': "Increase tox job timeouts to 90 minutes

With the gate being extra-busy due to feature freeze week, we seem to be
having even more of a noisy neighbor problem and jobs are still often
hitting the 60 minute timeout. This change increases the timeout from 60
to 90 minutes. This is not an indication that things are normal and fine
but should hopefully alleviate pressure until we're in a position to
merge a more satisfactory workaround and fix.

Change-Id: I171eccc2dd46c26ada74def36523c6f7f29be868
"}]
commit_message:
Increase tox job timeouts to 90 minutes

With the gate being extra-busy due to feature freeze week, we seem to be
having even more of a noisy neighbor problem and jobs are still often
hitting the 60 minute timeout. This change increases the timeout from 60
to 90 minutes. This is not an indication that things are normal and fine
but should hopefully alleviate pressure until we're in a position to
merge a more satisfactory workaround and fix.

Change-Id: I171eccc2dd46c26ada74def36523c6f7f29be868

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-12 09:26:33.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I3eff767cfa84ba0d6b0b5ebe62a12df76d9d67f4
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I3eff767cfa84ba0d6b0b5ebe62a12df76d9d67f4

Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Update master for stable/train

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/train.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/train.

Change-Id: Id5949d7df0efcb7ef09a75663c8f95e86cf5e828
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Enable pg_autoscaler for new Nautilus installations

This change also allows an admin to enable it for existing
installations that are upgraded to Nautilus via a config
option.

This change also enabled bionic-train to allow testing with
Ceph Nautilus.

func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/52
Depends-On: https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/343
Change-Id: Ic532204aa1576cdbeb47de7410f421aa9e4bac42

commit_message:
Remove unused settings in openstack_dashboard

IMAGE_RESERVED_CUSTOM_PROPERTIES has been not used since Juno.
commit 2e3299dc57e8dd90fe34e1621ea5282bda157563 drops the usage of
IMAGE_RESERVED_CUSTOM_PROPERTIES.

OPENSTACK_HEAT_STACK is specific to heat-dashboard and
it was moved to heat-dashboard.

FLAVOR_EXTRA_KEYS deprecation notice has been dropped. No code refers to
it for a long time (at least the recent four releases).

Part of blueprint ini-based-configuration
Change-Id: I1b81f3e437feafb18423225a93900b07ae91cc75

commit_message:
Define default settings explicitly (openstack_auth)

This commit also moves descriptions of settings defined in openstack_auth
from openstack_dashboard/settings.py and local_settings.py(.example)
to openstack_auth/settings.py.

Note that if openstack_dashboard has different default settings
from openstack_auth defaults, they are now moved to
openstack_dashboard/defaults.py.

Part of blueprint ini-based-configuration
Change-Id: I59eebc388de0bcbd4d1fe35c6138efbd3e04c5b8

[{'created': '2019-09-11 00:04:19.000000000', 'message': 'os-vif: release stein 1.15.2

This release contains bug fixes for:

  * [OSSA-2019-004] Ageing time of 0 disables linuxbridge MAC learning
    (CVE-2019-15753) (bug 1837252)
  * In OVS hybrid, avoid "qbr" from replying ARP packets if the IP is
    local in the system (bug 1825888)

Change-Id: If677bba2c657c8f68146bb173cca094229f9eced
'}]
commit_message:
os-vif: release stein 1.15.2

This release contains bug fixes for:

  * [OSSA-2019-004] Ageing time of 0 disables linuxbridge MAC learning
    (CVE-2019-15753) (bug 1837252)
  * In OVS hybrid, avoid "qbr" from replying ARP packets if the IP is
    local in the system (bug 1825888)

Change-Id: If677bba2c657c8f68146bb173cca094229f9eced

commit_message:
Store collect period in InfluxDB driver datapoints

This adds a field containing the cloudkitty period used when pushing data
into InfluxDB. Work items:

* Store the period along with the begin timestamp in the InfluxDB storage.

* Added a "diff_seconds()" function to "cloudkitty.tzutils". It calculates
  the difference in seconds between two "datetime.datetime" objects.

* Added unit tests for the "diff_seconds()" function.

Change-Id: I4af7adaf5044da2e0a44bbb30ba4a24742cd8a94

[{'created': '2018-02-01 19:54:57.000000000', 'message': "Fix bootstrap-servers with invalid api_interface

When bootstrapping a host for kolla-ansible the 'kolla-ansible
bootstrap-servers' command can fail if for any of the hosts the
'api_interface' is invalid. This happen if the host does not have a
network interface matching 'api_interface'. This is possible on
a host running bifrost, as bifrost does not require the api_interface
variable to be set.

This change avoids adding a hosts entry for hosts in the bifrost group
that do not have a valid api_interface. It also avoids modifying the
hosts file on hosts in the bifrost group that do not have a valid
api_interface.

Change-Id: Ie111ef54130adf2556ce83c402cdbb5058ace4f6
Closes-bug: #1665364
Related-Bug: #1726957
(cherry picked from commit 64b09d6eb0734249843bfc4f8fc8058222bf3804)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix bootstrap-servers with invalid api_interface

When bootstrapping a host for kolla-ansible the 'kolla-ansible
bootstrap-servers' command can fail if for any of the hosts the
'api_interface' is invalid. This happen if the host does not have a
network interface matching 'api_interface'. This is possible on
a host running bifrost, as bifrost does not require the api_interface
variable to be set.

This change avoids adding a hosts entry for hosts in the bifrost group
that do not have a valid api_interface. It also avoids modifying the
hosts file on hosts in the bifrost group that do not have a valid
api_interface.

Change-Id: Ie111ef54130adf2556ce83c402cdbb5058ace4f6
Closes-bug: #1665364
Related-Bug: #1726957
(cherry picked from commit 64b09d6eb0734249843bfc4f8fc8058222bf3804)

subject: Use new rules syntax for fluentd in centos
messages: [{'account_id': 11827, 'date': '2018-08-29 18:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-09-12 10:46:11.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nFluentd recently reworked'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-29 18:15:27.000000000', 'message': "Use new rules syntax for fluentd in centos

New Centos releases (tested on CentOS Linux release 7.4.1708 (Core)) use
Fluentd new enough to understand new <rule></rule> syntax for rewrites
as we see warnings about deprecated syntax in container logs with
Fluentd version of 0.12.42. If we look then we'll see that this version
of Fluentd ships with fluent-plugin-rewrite-tag-filter v 1.6.0 which is
already supports new ruleset syntax. Thus, add centos to the list of
releases which should use v0.14 rewrites config.

Change-Id: I9bc57b9111b2d9ca8f906765ba8edebb58a626e4
"}]
commit_message:
Use new rules syntax for fluentd in centos

New Centos releases (tested on CentOS Linux release 7.4.1708 (Core)) use
Fluentd new enough to understand new <rule></rule> syntax for rewrites
as we see warnings about deprecated syntax in container logs with
Fluentd version of 0.12.42. If we look then we'll see that this version
of Fluentd ships with fluent-plugin-rewrite-tag-filter v 1.6.0 which is
already supports new ruleset syntax. Thus, add centos to the list of
releases which should use v0.14 rewrites config.

Change-Id: I9bc57b9111b2d9ca8f906765ba8edebb58a626e4

commit_message:
Update min ansible version to 2.1.0

Ansible does not contain ansible_python in version 2.0.0.
But package_checks.yml is used ansible_python in ocata branch.
see:
https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/stable/ocata/ansible/roles/prechecks/tasks/package_checks.yml#L3

So,we need update min ansible version for ocata dependencies in quickstart.rst.

Change-Id: I710ef287785b38bc1556b9228bbccb074e8e2fd7

commit_message:
Fix doc:disable chronyd to make ntpd start on boot

chronyd is enabled by default in Centos 7. You should disable it
if you want to make ntpd start on boot.

Change-Id: Id1fa15004bbace3ce5f85e4831f5c701b6b78f64

- gate-kolla-dsvm-build-oraclelinux-binary-centos-7-nv http://logs.openstack.org/42/452742/1/check/gate-kolla-dsvm-build-oraclelinux-binary-centos-7-nv/c2f2c20/ : SUCCESS in 47m 29s (non-voting)
- gate-kolla-dsvm-deploy-oraclelinux-binary-centos-7-nv http://logs.openstack.org/42/452742/1/check/gate-kolla-dsvm-deploy-oraclelinux-binary-centos-7-nv/c19d182/ : SUCCESS in 34m 54s (non-voting)
- gate-kolla-dsvm-build-oraclelinux-source-centos-7 http://logs.openstack.org/42/452742/1/check/gate-kolla-dsvm-build-oraclelinux-source-centos-7/95a193c/ : SUCCESS in 1h 08m 11s
- gate-kolla-dsvm-deploy-oraclelinux-source-centos-7-nv http://logs.openstack.org/42/452742/1/check/gate-kolla-dsvm-deploy-oraclelinux-source-centos-7-nv/8e620fb/ : SUCCESS in 33m 48s (non-voting)
- kolla-coverage-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/42/452742/1/check/kolla-coverage-ubuntu-xenial-nv/7f5c2da/ : SUCCESS in 1m 35s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2017-04-03 14:14:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes it's possible to use config.json! At first I got fooled by the badly named 'permissions' key in config.json that does not set permissions at all but ownership.

If we go the config.json route, we're back to square one where all of the deployment tools need to set the permissions themselves. I don't mean it's bad, but is it were we want to go? Right now it's a bit of a grey area where some operations are taken care of by kolla boostrap, and others by the deployment tools. Where do we draw the line?"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2017-04-03 14:20:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

note http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-April/114894.html'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2017-04-03 14:31:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This looks valid and sane, thank you Martin! However, new files, if created by deployment tools as owned by root, will end up with "permission denied" when accessed from containers running as non root. I wonder, if setting "chmod s+g /foo/dir" could fit the generic deployment tools' use cases better?..'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2017-04-03 14:38:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Even more (IIUC), when those dirs are hostpath mounted to containers, the permissions mismatch for new files could be an issue even if these directories are owned by some non root user having ID that differs to the same user's ID inside of the container. Here also come user namespaces nuances for containers, in which I'm not an expert, I must admit..."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2017-04-04 15:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2017-04-15 05:46:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

> Yes it's possible to use config.json! At first I got fooled by the
 > badly named 'permissions' key in config.json that does not set
 > permissions at all but ownership.
 > 
 > If we go the config.json route, we're back to square one where all
 > of the deployment tools need to set the permissions themselves. I
 > don't mean it's bad, but is it were we want to go? Right now it's a
 > bit of a grey area where some operations are taken care of by kolla
 > boostrap, and others by the deployment tools. Where do we draw the
 > line?

Martin,

Indeed the mismatch between the containers setting permissions and config.json setting permissions is a bit of a difficulty.  I think expecting the containers to do all of the permission setting seems like a major overhaul.  I think config.json is not really a "back to square one" or a "reset" but more like a "how does a deployment tool want to manage the security of the container?"

I really don't have a great answer for you.  I would highly recommend adding this topic to the meeting agenda for April 19th as this probably affects a wide swath of folks in various ways I don't personally understand.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 03:30:14.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-09-12 10:41:24.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Almost 2 years old'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-04-03 12:53:42.000000000', 'message': 'Set ownership of persistent data directories recursively

This is necessary in the case of upgrade from baremetal to containers
and avoid all of the deployment tools to deal with the same issues.

Change-Id: Iefad4a8b40cfc31712aadceaaf8d67d66e37df1b
'}]
commit_message:
Set ownership of persistent data directories recursively

This is necessary in the case of upgrade from baremetal to containers
and avoid all of the deployment tools to deal with the same issues.

Change-Id: Iefad4a8b40cfc31712aadceaaf8d67d66e37df1b

The kubernetes project provides official deb and rpm packages. Prefer
them over the static binary for binary install types.

Change-Id: I00dd38ffea66d6f3214e7465680302baa510c6f4
'}]
commit_message:
Install kubelet from official repos for binary type

The kubernetes project provides official deb and rpm packages. Prefer
them over the static binary for binary install types.

Change-Id: I00dd38ffea66d6f3214e7465680302baa510c6f4

commit_message:
Add After=mariadb.service postgresql.service rabbitmq-server.service

Adding theses lines to the systemd .service files will help to order
the boot/shutdown process when the database and/or RabbitMQ are
running on the same node as the service.

Also done:
- for glance-api, explicitly call glance-manage with config-dir to be
  able to add config snippets to /etc/glance/glance-api.conf.d/
- Drop some empty lines in the .service files

Change-Id: Id9c36226289304adb7ef2438f6bc2de1dde9e144

commit_message:
neutron: Execute unittests during %check and enable doc build

- unittests were disabled. This is now enabled. Also missing
- BuildRequires are added to let the tests pass.
- Enable doc build by default. We want to have the docs available

Change-Id: I9755a1e177bf9ceac7edebeee892be591e0f8b16

subject: Stop race condition error when unit tests write to DB
messages:
[{'account_id': 30793, 'date': '2019-09-09 01:02:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2019-09-10 22:54:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Better mocking for the win!'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-09-12 10:07:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Edin; thanks for the bug fix.  For future reference, if the patch fixes a bug (which in this case it does), it's helpful to include a "Closes-Bug: #1841806" in the commit message.  This automatically notifies launchpad of the patch and that it has been fixed.  See https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#development-workflow for more details.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-09 01:02:19.000000000', 'message': 'Stop race condition error when unit tests write to DB

In test environments where multiple CPUs are available and tests can
be run concurrently, the two test cases patched here can both generate
INSERT statements. The first completed test case will commit
successfully. The subsequent test case will also attempt to
INSERT (with the same primary key), resulting in an SQL integrity
error.

For a full break-down of the race condition please see:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-nova-cloud-controller/+bug/1841806/comments/5

Change-Id: I0b8d4d7544e76c1c11c928fd7325259186d9ff53
'}]
commit_message:
Stop race condition error when unit tests write to DB

In test environments where multiple CPUs are available and tests can
be run concurrently, the two test cases patched here can both generate
INSERT statements. The first completed test case will commit
successfully. The subsequent test case will also attempt to
INSERT (with the same primary key), resulting in an SQL integrity
error.

For a full break-down of the race condition please see:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-nova-cloud-controller/+bug/1841806/comments/5

Change-Id: I0b8d4d7544e76c1c11c928fd7325259186d9ff53

commit_message:
Release python-troveclient 3.0.0

Reason for the major version bump:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681425/ introduced a backward
incompatible change that trove CLI only supports one item for the
``--nic`` parameter.

Change-Id: Id79e06af6a0c342a0c19e5757dfd2b24735fe5d3
Story: 2006500
Task: 36578

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-11 15:48:08.000000000', 'message': 'new-release: Drop tarball-base from individual releases

We now track explicit tarball base names at a top level under
repository-settings instead of per release. The only time it should be
needed per release is if a project changes their package name part way
through the cycle.

Since most teams are now publishing to pypi and have worked through
needing to rename their packages, it should be safe to update
new-release to not include the tarball-base override per individual
project in a release.

Change-Id: If1c77e358b48113a7fb4d7a48ed8d31841ab9419
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
new-release: Drop tarball-base from individual releases

We now track explicit tarball base names at a top level under
repository-settings instead of per release. The only time it should be
needed per release is if a project changes their package name part way
through the cycle.

Since most teams are now publishing to pypi and have worked through
needing to rename their packages, it should be safe to update
new-release to not include the tarball-base override per individual
project in a release.

Change-Id: If1c77e358b48113a7fb4d7a48ed8d31841ab9419
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Pass 'type' as metric_types in /v2/summary endpoints

This extracts the 'type' filter in the /v2/summary endpoint, and passes
it to the storage driver through the 'metric_types' parameter instead.

This is done in order to be able to support a filter on multiple types in
the future.

Change-Id: Idee055ef99dc82ed577b8ae5680a62abafb71a5a

commit_message:
nova: Fix with_doc=0 build and run unittests

- The build without docs was broken because the man pages are not
  available then. Fixed now.
- Enable unittest run in %check section. Previously the unittests run
  was disabled.
  Also some BuildRequires added to fix the tests.

Change-Id: I46044096078b51f75234cc867987465d357c7d76

[{'account_id': 26387, 'date': '2018-10-11 09:29:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-10-11 09:30:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know

Why is the existing driver not being updated instead:

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/cinder/tree/cinder/volume/drivers/fujitsu

If this is different, it should be renamed to be more clear which is which, because right now they are too similarly named for someone to know what which one to use.

If just updating the existing one, make changes to that instead of submitting an entirely new driver. Then a mapping can be added in cinder/volume/manager.py to handle the new module path.

Also needs updates to the driver docs and a release note.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-11 12:46:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Sean, Hi Sean, I am very sorry because I did not explain my submission.
Your suggestion (I'am not update the existing one).I really want to fix it. But I can't do it. Because I cannot move and modify file with more than 50% modification. So I submit separately. when the move path merged, I rebase this path and commit it.

About The Zuul Check, I've seen it, I am very sorry that I have not set the workflow to -1.
BTW, I Have some questions about the Zuul check.
* In the openstack-tox-lower-constraints, the error is (AttributeError: module \'OpenSSL.SSL\' has no attribute \'SSL_ST_INIT\'\n'). Because we import the SSL from eventlet.green.OpenSSL. I don't know how to fix it. Can you give me a hint?
* In the requirements-check, I add requirement pywbem to doc-requirements, Because it have error in openstack-tox-docs in the previous commit, which says have no package named pywbem, I dont know why openstack-tox-docs need the third-party package pywbem.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-11 09:29:55.000000000', 'message': 'This driver supports FUJITSU Storage ETERNUS DX.
This version used the different Storage interface, and did some Performance optimization.

[Supported Protocol]
 - iSCSI
 - FC

[Supported Feature]
 - Volume Create/Delete
 - Volume Attach/Detach
 - Snapshot Create/Delete
 - Create Volume from Snapshot
 - Get Volume Stats
 - Copy Image to Volume
 - Copy Volume to Image
 - Clone Volume
 - Extend Volume

Change-Id: I60c35fe25c60d4ac6f6147a56d1a6b76dafae656
Implements: blueprint fujitsu-eternus-dx-driver-update
'}, {'created': '2018-12-08 02:34:45.000000000', 'message': 'This driver supports FUJITSU Storage ETERNUS DX.
This version used the different Storage interface, and did some Performance optimization.
This version optimized some features. After successful merge, the old ones will be deleted.

[Supported Protocol]
 - iSCSI
 - FC

[Supported Feature]
 - Volume Create/Delete
 - Volume Attach/Detach
 - Snapshot Create/Delete
 - Create Volume from Snapshot
 - Get Volume Stats
 - Copy Image to Volume
 - Copy Volume to Image
 - Clone Volume
 - Extend Volume
 - Manage Volume
 - Migrate Volume
 - Failover Host
Change-Id: I60c35fe25c60d4ac6f6147a56d1a6b76dafae656

commit_message:
Update Fujitsu ETERNUS DX driver

This version used the different Storage interface, and did some
Performance optimization.This version optimized some features.

[Supported Protocol]
 - iSCSI
 - FC

[Supported Feature]
 - Volume Create/Delete
 - Volume Attach/Detach
 - Snapshot Create/Delete
 - Create Volume from Snapshot
 - Get Volume Stats
 - Copy Image to Volume
 - Copy Volume to Image
 - Clone Volume
 - Extend Volume
 - Manage Volume
 - Migrate Volume
 - Failover Host
Change-Id: I60c35fe25c60d4ac6f6147a56d1a6b76dafae656
Implements: blueprint fujitsu-eternus-dx-driver-update

[{'created': '2019-09-11 14:45:49.000000000', 'message': 'Add dependencies for ubuntu

Bifrost sets up iptables rules. Especially in container
environments this package may be missing, so bifrost should
install it as a requirement.
Additionally iscsi deployments rely on hexdump, which is part of

commit_message:
Add dependencies for ubuntu

Bifrost sets up iptables rules. Especially in container
environments this package may be missing, so bifrost should
install it as a requirement.
Additionally iscsi deployments rely on hexdump, which is part of
bsdmainutils, which may be missing as well.

Change-Id: I2fe16e572ff0705248d842d93ea178bf0f8b35b4

commit_message:
Install dumb-init rpm

By default it's installed from source. Let's override it to
install the rpm.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/680125
Change-Id: I42745941c2d69138d8254dd396b7b110fff96a0f
(cherry picked from commit 06b38c4ff8ad5d345ab09cf21a194416a8b9ebb4)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-30 16:42:47.000000000', 'message': 'Create _mech_context before delete to avoid race

When a network is deleted, precommit handlers are notified prior to the
deletion of the network from the database. One handler exists in the ML2
plugin - _network_delete_precommit_handler. This handler queries the
database for the current state of the network and uses it to create a
NetworkContext which it saves under context._mech_context. When the
postcommit handler _network_delete_after_delete_handler is triggered
later, it passess the saved context._mech_context to mechanism drivers.

A problem can occur with provider networks since the segments service
also registers a precommit handler - _delete_segments_for_network. Both
precommit handlers use the default priority, so the order in which they
are called is random, and determined by dict ordering. If the segment
precommit handler executes first, it will delete the segments associated
with the network. When the ML2 plugin precommit handler runs it then
sees no segments for the network and sets the provider attributes of the
network in the NetworkContext to None.

A mechanism driver that is passed a NetworkContext without provider
attributes in its delete_network_postcommit method will not have the
information to perform the necessary actions.  In the case of the
networking-generic-switch mechanism driver where this was observed, this
resulted in the driver ignoring the event, because the network did not
look like a VLAN.

This change adds an additional callback registration to the ML2 plugin
for BEFORE_DELETE, which is used to query the network and store the
NetworkContext before the segments service has a chance to delete
segments.

A similar change has been made for subnets, both to keep the pattern
consistent and avoid any similar issues.

Finally, context._mech_context has been renamed to
context._network_mech_context or context._subnet_mech_context to avoid
overwriting the network context with a subnet context when a network
deletion triggers a subnet deletion.

Change-Id: I6482223ed2a479de4f5ef4cef056c311c0281408
Closes-Bug: #1841967

commit_message:
Create _mech_context before delete to avoid race

When a network is deleted, precommit handlers are notified prior to the
deletion of the network from the database. One handler exists in the ML2
plugin - _network_delete_precommit_handler. This handler queries the
database for the current state of the network and uses it to create a
NetworkContext which it saves under context._mech_context. When the
postcommit handler _network_delete_after_delete_handler is triggered
later, it passess the saved context._mech_context to mechanism drivers.

A problem can occur with provider networks since the segments service
also registers a precommit handler - _delete_segments_for_network. Both
precommit handlers use the default priority, so the order in which they
are called is random, and determined by dict ordering. If the segment
precommit handler executes first, it will delete the segments associated
with the network. When the ML2 plugin precommit handler runs it then
sees no segments for the network and sets the provider attributes of the
network in the NetworkContext to None.

A mechanism driver that is passed a NetworkContext without provider
attributes in its delete_network_postcommit method will not have the
information to perform the necessary actions.  In the case of the
networking-generic-switch mechanism driver where this was observed, this
resulted in the driver ignoring the event, because the network did not
look like a VLAN.

This change uses a priority of zero for ML2 network delete precommit
handler, to ensure they query the network and store the NetworkContext
before the segments service has a chance to delete segments.

A similar change has been made for subnets, both to keep the pattern
consistent and avoid any similar issues.

Change-Id: I6482223ed2a479de4f5ef4cef056c311c0281408
Closes-Bug: #1841967
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/680001

messages:
[{'account_id': 30970, 'date': '2019-09-12 04:38:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-09-12 04:39:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30970, 'date': '2019-09-12 07:41:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

commit_message:
Versioned Writes checks for SLO object before copy

versioned_writes middleware will now check for SLO header to add query 'multipart-manifest=put' if necessary before performing copy from current to versioned container

Change-Id: Iebf04c2357b5481e7d236fbb400d21a307f3ef4a
Closes-Bug: #1840322

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-30 13:01:37.000000000', 'message': 'Delay HA router transition from "backup" to "master"

As described in the bug, when a HA router transitions from "master" to
"backup", "keepalived" processes will set the virtual IP in all other
HA routers. Each HA router will then advert it and "keepalived" will
decide, according to a trivial algorithm (higher interface IP), which
one should be "master". At this point, the other "keepalived" processes
running in the other servers, will remove the HA router virtual IP
assigned an instant before

To avoid transitioning some routers form "backup" to "master" and then
to "backup" in a very short period, this patch delays the "backup" to
"master" transition, waiting for a possible new "backup" state. If
during the waiting period (set to the HA VRRP advert time, 2 seconds
default) to set the HA state to "master", the L3 agent receives a new
"backup" HA state, the L3 agent does nothing.

Closes-Bug: #1837635

Change-Id: I70037da9cdd0f8448e0af8dd96b4e3f5de5728ad
(cherry picked from commit 3f022a193f66fde3bfd945af1119a60dfe91cb91)

commit_message:
Delay HA router transition from "backup" to "master"

As described in the bug, when a HA router transitions from "master" to
"backup", "keepalived" processes will set the virtual IP in all other
HA routers. Each HA router will then advert it and "keepalived" will
decide, according to a trivial algorithm (higher interface IP), which
one should be "master". At this point, the other "keepalived" processes
running in the other servers, will remove the HA router virtual IP
assigned an instant before

To avoid transitioning some routers form "backup" to "master" and then
to "backup" in a very short period, this patch delays the "backup" to
"master" transition, waiting for a possible new "backup" state. If
during the waiting period (set to the HA VRRP advert time, 2 seconds
default) to set the HA state to "master", the L3 agent receives a new
"backup" HA state, the L3 agent does nothing.

Closes-Bug: #1837635

Change-Id: I70037da9cdd0f8448e0af8dd96b4e3f5de5728ad
(cherry picked from commit 3f022a193f66fde3bfd945af1119a60dfe91cb91)

commit_message:
Remove redundant exception handling

Some interfaces have been treated abnormally in [1] and [2],
The exception has been processed using handle_errors,
there is no need to do additional processing later.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/mistral-dashboard/blob/master/mistraldashboard/api.py#L358-L365
[2] https://github.com/openstack/mistral-dashboard/blob/master/mistraldashboard/api.py#L347-L355

Change-Id: I0dd4709072e23615054d4c8511f0766bab3a62ea

commit_message:
Support RPC over plain HTTP (vs gRPC)

Support for plain HTTP communication between object server and index
server. gRPC support is removed in this patch.

Communication still happens over a UNIX domain socket, and protobuf is
still used to exchange data between the object server and the index
server.

- The existing interface of the python rpc module is preserved. The only
change in the caller code is "import rpc_http as rpc" vs "import
rpc_grpc as rpc".

Known issues:
- RPC Exceptions are not exactly similar to existing exceptions, and
need review in caller (vfile.py)
- some golang and python unit tests need changing (WIP)

Change-Id: I4419d56826a28b95503c84a81ff9e2d87b0adb68

commit_message:
Add support to enable l3 port-forwarding plugin

Allows enabling neutron port forwarding plugin
and l3 extension to forward ports from floating
IP to a fixed neutron port.

Change-Id: Ic25c96a0ddcf4f69acbfb7a58acafec82c3b0aed
Implements: blueprint enable-l3-port-forwarding
(cherry picked from commit 1662a77b55e3f4c9e512aff83d3a065b894c41b3)

subject: py3: (mostly) port probe tests
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-17 16:58:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-17 17:00:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Tested on a VSAIO running py3. Definitely needs

- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671167/ (fix sharded listings)
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670932/ (fix swift-orphans)

Maybe needs

- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670933/ (fix rsync output parsing)
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/671168/ (fix socket.error errno checking)'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-17 18:46:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2019-08-24 00:18:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I have an embarrassing question: why the wholesale replacement of set() with a dict {}? I wrote a couple of small tests and it appears that len(set()) works in py3 as expected.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-26 23:44:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I decided to try out https://pypi.org/project/flake8-comprehensions/ and now I can't help myself ;-) All the sets should still be sets;

 {1, 2, 3}

is the same as

 set([1, 2, 3])

I'm happy to back them out if you'd rather avoid the churn, though. Maybe that'd be better for readability, so the set comprehensions aren't confused for dict comprehensions?"}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2019-08-27 02:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2019-08-27 02:47:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

>  All the sets should still be sets;
 > 
 > {1, 2, 3}
 > 
 > is the same as
 > 
 > set([1, 2, 3])
 > 
 > I'm happy to back them out if you'd rather avoid the churn, though.
 > Maybe that'd be better for readability, so the set comprehensions
 > aren't confused for dict comprehensions?

I missed the lack of colons. So the isomorphic question is
if we have anyone else on core who programmed in Python
for 10 years without actually knowing Python. If yes, then
better back those out :-)"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-28 17:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-28 17:21:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Rebased, with some minor fixes for some newly-added tests. TestReconstructorRebuildUTF8 is still busted.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-28 19:10:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2019-08-28 20:10:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-09-04 05:17:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Looks great. Although I think a print() snuck through from your debugging (see inline)

Once that's fixed, let's get it in."}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2019-09-04 16:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-09-04 17:17:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-09-04 17:18:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

Good catch, thanks guys.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2019-09-04 17:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-09-11 21:07:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-17 16:58:40.000000000', 'message': "py3: (mostly) port probe tests

There's still one problem, though: since swiftclient on py3 doesn't
support non-ASCII characters in metadata names, none of the tests in
TestReconstructorRebuildUTF8 will pass.

commit_message:
py3: (mostly) port probe tests

There's still one problem, though: since swiftclient on py3 doesn't
support non-ASCII characters in metadata names, none of the tests in
TestReconstructorRebuildUTF8 will pass.

Change-Id: I4ec879ade534e09c3a625414d8aa1f16fd600fa4

commit_message:
Document the incompatibility of trunk ports with iptables_hybrid fw

We seem to have forgot to properly document this limitation and this
is popping up in bug reports.

Partial-Bug: #1843285

commit_message:
Support reporting multi CPU model traits

Change existing method: '_get_cpu_traits'. Make it support report multi
CPU model's traits.

Change-Id: I448f9fe02acda111aa90b3ea17e53bc0c27cd09d
Implements: blueprint cpu-model-selection

commit_message:
Updating mapping rule link

This is the closest I could find to backport.
The correct content is available in /latest/
but not for Rocky.

Change-Id: I854a4c5e740f8b0c9d1173daf6d62f78c7c97b7f

commit_message:
k8s_fedora_atomic: Add PodSecurityPolicy

For moving to 1.15.x and beyond we need to have PSP for privileged pods.
flannel, calico and node-problem-detector need it.

PSP
story: 2006515
task: 36513

Allow-priv
story: 2006252
task: 35867

Change-Id: I306a249afb275fdbd71354ed75043ffc4d466304
Signed-off-by: Spyros Trigazis <spyridon.trigazis@cern.ch>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-11 12:59:52.000000000', 'message': "vCPU mdoels selection

Rename the exist config attribute: [libvirt]/cpu_model to
[libvirt]/cpu_models, which is an orderd list of CPU models the host
supports. The value in the list can be made case-insensitive.

Change logic of method: '_get_guest_cpu_model_config', if cpu_mode is
custom and cpu_models setted. It will parse the required traits
associated with the CPU flags from flavor extra_specs and select the
most appropriate CPU model.

Add new method 'get_cpu_model_names' to host.py. It will return a list
of the cpu models that the CPU arch can support.

Remove some of the compatibility checks for cpu_mode and cpu_models,
they will be moved to service init part in next patch.

Change-Id: I06e1f7429c056c4ce8506b10359762e457dbb2a0

commit_message:
vCPU model selection

Rename the exist config attribute: [libvirt]/cpu_model to
[libvirt]/cpu_models, which is an orderded list of CPU models the host
supports. The value in the list can be made case-insensitive.

Change logic of method: '_get_guest_cpu_model_config', if cpu_mode is
custom and cpu_models set. It will parse the required traits
associated with the CPU flags from flavor extra_specs and select the
most appropriate CPU model.

Add new method 'get_cpu_model_names' to host.py. It will return a list
of the cpu models that the CPU arch can support.

Update the docs of hypervisor-kvm.

Change-Id: I06e1f7429c056c4ce8506b10359762e457dbb2a0
Implements: blueprint cpu-model-selection

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Miscellaneous improvements to delete

1.  Remove rollback code to re-add volume to storage group as this operation
is really not necessary on a delete operation.
2.  Change certain error messages to debugs as these can be misleading
when debugging the logs.
3.  Check if source volume is still on the array, if not a sync check is
unnecessary.

Change-Id: Id261176018c81704d7551a661a0270407f00658a

Or if we do not have a reason to increase the lower bound version, use this in requirements.txt 
eventlet!=0.23.0,!=0.25.0,>=0.18.2

The key is that lower constraint has to match the lower bound specified in requirements.txt."}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2019-09-11 18:46:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2019-09-11 18:49:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2019-09-11 18:53:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

fast approving to unblock'}]

commit_message:
Blacklist eventlet 0.23.0, 0.25.0

Kombu 4.6.4 causes issues with eventlet 0.23.0 and 0.25.0[1].
Due to an upper-constraint version bump, we're seeing failures
on openstack gate.
This patch fixes the issue.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/678078

Change-Id: Iad5c736e3fc817c0cca1f142dbba71ef7e594cef

(1 comment)

The functional failure [1] is a race in the already merged functional test as the migration allocation is deleted _after_ the migration is set to confirmed and the instance is set to ACTIVE. Will propose a follow up to decrease the race window but there is no way to prevent it as the migration delete is the last thing that happens.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-13 09:17:00.000000000', 'message': 'Make _rever_allocation nested allocation aware

As we are introducing migrate / resize revert for servers with nested
allocation (servers with ports having bandwidth resource request) we
need to make the allocation revert process aware of more than one
resouce providers in the original allocation held by the migration.

Change-Id: Ie90204f05f57a42f7df05fe40c9c5a7f30cb578e
blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports

commit_message:
Make _revert_allocation nested allocation aware

As we are introducing migrate / resize revert for servers with nested
allocation (servers with ports having bandwidth resource request) we
need to make the allocation revert process aware of more than one
resouce providers in the original allocation held by the migration.

Change-Id: Ie90204f05f57a42f7df05fe40c9c5a7f30cb578e
blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports

commit_message:
Ensure python3-systemd is present on all hosts for suse systems

This patch is required temporarily until the suse oslo.log package has a
dependancy on python3-systemd.

Change-Id: I226e2ee84732dde18fe7e47b28003e26ae0c955a

I tested the upgrade process in two nodes env as below:

Upgrade control plane and one of compute node
Boot the instance successful on old and new compute node
     On new node, the instance consumes PCPU
     On old node, the instance consumes VCPU
Upgrade the second compute node
Boot the instance sucessful both on the old and new compute node.
      Both old and new node, the instance consumes PCPU'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2019-09-11 08:02:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-37017 : FAILURE in 1h 00m 22s'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-09-11 09:07:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I found one problem.

I have two hosts.

One host is on new version. Another host on old version.

And I have an instance on the old host.

When I try to resize the instance, and old host doesn't allow same host resize.

So the placement still try to return the allocation candidates for the old host, but the nova-schediler filter will ignore the old host. In the end the resize failed."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-09-11 09:08:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-09-11 10:09:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Okay, I *definitely* don't think we should be doing this by default (if at all). As written, if I've upgraded (some or all computes) and am genuinely out of PCPUs, I'll fall back to VCPU, which seems like very bad behavior. We may not want to make it conditional on service versions, but we should at least make it conditional on a config opt -- and off by default."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-09-11 11:16:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

commit_message:
doc: Add support microversions for options

Add descriptions of support microversions for the '--marker' option
and the '--limit' option in the 'nova hypervisor-list' command
in the CLI reference.

Change-Id: Ie25e848b51fd0220e318393db123c97b4a642091
Closes-Bug: #1616450

I'm going to -W this because through people's testing issues are being unearthed that make this unsuitable for merging at this stage.

For instance, I got an email from Windriver folks that the instance_numa_topology isn't being updated in the database, despite apply_migration_context() being called in post_live_migration. Maybe it's racing with something on the source?

At any rate, I'm happy that this is being tested in various places (Intel, Windriver), so let's keep this momentum going, take the time to work out the kinks after FF, and aim to land this early in Train."}, {'account_id': 19124, 'date': '2019-03-05 18:57:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

NOTE(artom): WIP until the whole series is ready. Currently the
periodic resource audit on the destination doesn't pick up resources
used by the incoming instance, leading to, for example, its CPUs not
being counded as used. This was pointed out by Windriver at the end of
Stein.

Add live_migration_claim() to the resource tracker. It returns a
MoveClaim object that, in subsequent patches, will be used during live
migrations to claim resources on the destination.

Implements blueprint numa-aware-live-migration
Change-Id: I3bafebe86991f457569efcd7b6f130c5a0080437
"}, {'created': '2019-07-29 21:22:16.000000000', 'message': "[WIP-until-series-is-ready] Introduce live_migration_claim()

up a bunch of test when addressing some feedback and doing some
refactoring. Once that's sorted, the series will be un-WIP'ed.

Add live_migration_claim() to the resource tracker. It returns a
MoveClaim object that, in subsequent patches, will be used during live
migrations to claim resources on the destination.

Implements blueprint numa-aware-live-migration
